solution.text:
amount of money deposited(p) = _{j}_
compound interest(r) rate= _{k}_% per year.
amount of money accumulated(A) after t years can be calculated by using, \(A=p*(1+(r*.01))^t\)
To find the first number of the list we take \(t=1\) and get \(_{{j*(1+(k*0.01))}}_\)
To find the second number of the list we take \(t=2\) and get \(_{{j*(1+(k*0.01))*(1+(k*0.01))}}_\)
To find the third number of the list we take \(t=3\) and get \(_{{j*(1+(k*.01))*(1+(k*.01))*(1+(k*.01))}}_\)
By taking difference of the two consecutive terms of the list \(_{{j*(1+(k*.01))}}_,_{{j*(1+(k*.01))*(1+(k*.01))}}_,_{{j*(1+(k*.01))*(1+(k*.01))*(1+(k*.01))}}_\)
We clearly see that \(a_2-a_1\) is not equal to \(a_3-a_2\)
Therefore this list doesn't form an AP

content.text: Ram deposited Rs _{j}_ at compound interest at _{k}_ % per annum. If the money in the account every year is taken to form a list of numbers, does the list forms an arithmetic progression.
